title: Lookout Points
subtitle: The secret to navigating the long, winding road of chronic disease
author: Tricia Steele
content_html:
Every time we drive back to our home near the top of Mt. Oglethorpe, we inevitably see the same sights as we wind to and fro and climb to our neighborhood three-thousand feet in elevation. From town, we mostly see low clouds, but as we make our way, we pass an overlook. The metal fence guard makes it unappealing as anything but a way to pull off and let the impatient speedster get on around. However, from this spot, we can see another point in the distance. And after another few miles, there is an even more spacious lookout spot perfect for trunk picnics, teenage graffiti and necking, and taking selfies with the haze of the Blue Ridge mountains and twinkle of small town Georgia as a backdrop.

From this higher vantage point, the lower lookout is fully visible and we see how very close it actually is to town, barely elevated at all it seems. And, then we turn left from the sunset and know our house is hidden another several miles and several dozen swerves and ear pops ahead.

March 1st is like that lookout point to me. On this day five years ago, I went to the doctor out of breath and came home five days later from the hospital with two chest tube and two scalpel scars. I had new knowledge about why I had experienced pain nearly every month for nearly a decade, but little understanding as to why and even less certainty it would stop even after all those cuts and stitches.

A year later to the day it was three additional surgeries and chest tubes later, and the answers were more clear even as a post-menopausal hot flash triggered yet another collapse and procedure.

All chronic disease has this circular feel to it. We come round and round to flares and occurrences, and it can feel endless. The climb can feel achingly slow, prone to as many downs as ups. But, the dates and anniversaries help us mark some kind of forward movement, help us see some progress even if the view is frustratingly familiar. I look back after five years and I see how very little I knew when I thought I had conquered so much.

Carve out for yourself lookout points. Find dates to circle on the calendars or scars to watch fade over time so that you know you are moving. Though you may be circling a mountain of confusion and suffering, take time to look back on the road that brought you here. Recognize your path and appreciate the body that carried you through whatever rough patch you had to battle. If you can take a breath, then you can take the next step. And one day, even this place too will be behind you.
